newsitem.title: FRANCE: Arthuis-Pension fund payouts should be annuities.
newsitem.headline: Arthuis-Pension fund payouts should be annuities.

text.p: French Finance Minister Jean Arthuis said on Monday that pension funds to be introduced next year should make payouts in annuities rather than lump sums.

In an interview with financial daily l'Agefi, he also said the introduction of pension funds would favour investment in shares, bolster company share capital and reduce the need for cross-shareholdings in French companies.
Arthuis said the main aim of introducing pension funds was to complement the existing system of universal pensions.

"That is the reason why I favour payouts in annuities, which will allow the subscriber to have a regular extra income at retirement age, and which will favour long-term investment," he said in the interview with l'Agefi.
Prime Minister Alain Juppe has suggested that there could be an option to choose to take money out in a lump sum.
French banks have pushed for pension funds to be able to pay out money in a lump sum, whereas insurance companies want the payout to be in the form of annuities.
The National Assembly is due to hold a debate on introducing pension funds this autumn.

But in a snub to Arthuis, whose ministry drew up detailed proposals on pension funds, parliament will debate not his proposals, but a bill drawn up in 1994 by then parliamentary deputies Jacques Barrot, Charles Millon and Jean-Pierre Thomas,
Arthuis said pension fund managers would naturally invest in shares, generally recognised to be more productive over the long term. This in turn would boost corporate share capital.

"The appearance of cross-shareholdings in privatisations, when these do not correspond to a need for a strong strategic partner, has been partly due to insufficient corporate share capital," he said. "Retirement funds investing in shares will ease this constraint."
Recent privatisations had shown that the construction of cross-shareholders were not essential, he said.
Discussion about the introduction of pension funds is being closely watched by financial markets, interested to see whether it would affect the allocation of assets between stocks and bonds.
Arthuis's proposals do not suggest fixing a minimum for investment in shares or bonds, which finance ministry sources say they do not believe to be necessary as long as payouts are in annuities.
The National Assembly, the lower house of parliament, has not yet fixed a date for its debate on pension funds, but may do so on Tuesday at a meeting of heads of parliamentary parties.
Arthuis is expected to try to amend the draft bill during the parliamentary debate to bring it back to his own original proposals. -- Paris Newsroom +33 1 42 21 53 81
